headline.main: OBSCURE GERMAN PILGRIMS STAR IN A TRICENTENNIAL

results.snippet: Three hundred years ago, 13 families from Krefeld, subjects of the Dutch House of Orange, left their homes to make a new life in a God-fearing community being founded in America by an Englishman named William Penn.   The few scholars who have...

byline.original: By JAMES M. MARKHAM, Special to the New York Times

results.lead_paragraph: Three hundred years ago, 13 families from Krefeld, subjects of the Dutch House of Orange, left their homes to make a new life in a God-fearing community being founded in America by an Englishman named William Penn. The few scholars who have investigated this modest emigration to Penn's Holy Experiment cannot agree whether the Krefelders were Mennonites or Quakers. While the Krefelders spoke German, some of their names - such as op den Graeff - are evidently Dutch, and Penn himself referred to them as Hollanders. Until 1983, the Krefeld pilgrims and the Concord, the ship that carried them from Gravesend in England to what is now Philadelphia in 1683, were decidedly obscure.

results.snippet: To a strong musical beat, melted cherry ice cream drips onto a woman sunning herself on a beach. A young man in a bathing suit sings about a woman who boards his yacht, her body painted orange, blue and green. Nearby, on an oceangoing raft, another...

byline.original: By Ed Levine; Ed Levine writes frequently on music and the music business

results.lead_paragraph: To a strong musical beat, melted cherry ice cream drips onto a woman sunning herself on a beach. A young man in a bathing suit sings about a woman who boards his yacht, her body painted orange, blue and green. Nearby, on an oceangoing raft, another man plays a saxophone. Next on the television screen: An oil sheik emerges from a fastfood restaurant, munching a hamburger. A fatigue-clad rock band, surrounded by oil derricks, sings about ''rockin' the casbah.'' An armadillo crosses a road. A rocket ship lands on the moon; an astronaut emerges to plant a flag bearing the initials MTV. Voiceover: ''MTV, the world's first video-music channel.''

results.snippet: Senator Alan Cranston has had one day off since January, and most nights find him in hotels far from home. When it rains he takes his habitual morning run in the corridors, confident that someday he will have a spectacular, blind-corner collision...

byline.original: By HOWELL RAINES, Special to the New York Times

results.lead_paragraph: Senator Alan Cranston has had one day off since January, and most nights find him in hotels far from home. When it rains he takes his habitual morning run in the corridors, confident that someday he will have a spectacular, blind-corner collision with a waiter from room service. At their simplest, these exertions are intended to convince voters that the oldest Democratic Presidential candidate is also the ''most vigorous.'' But the 68-year-old Californian also has a deeper purpose. He is determined, by brute persistence in the face of doubt, to make the Democratic Party take his candidacy seriously.

results.snippet: The space agency edged a $100 million communication satellite 284 miles deeper into space today as it initiated a methodical plan to elevate the craft to a stable orbit 22,300 miles above the earth.   The National Aeronautics and Space...
results.lead_paragraph: The space agency edged a $100 million communication satellite 284 miles deeper into space today as it initiated a methodical plan to elevate the craft to a stable orbit 22,300 miles above the earth. The National Aeronautics and Space Administration had to cut the maneuvers short because two thrusting jets on the satellite overheated, but officials were still satisfied with the progress they had made and planned to continue Wednesday, a spokesman said. The small jets were commanded by radio signal to fire over a period of 1 hour 22 minutes, leaving the Tracking and Data Relay Satellite in a lopsided orbit 14,222 to 21,962 miles high.

headline.main: GLENN LEADS MONDALE AS VOTE-GETTER IN GALLUP POLL

results.snippet: A new Gallup Poll projects Senator John Glenn as a stronger vote-getter than former Vice President Walter F.  Mondale in a general election race against President Reagan.   On the heels of a Los Angeles Times poll that showed Mr. Mondale and...

byline.original: Special to the New York Times

results.lead_paragraph: A new Gallup Poll projects Senator John Glenn as a stronger vote-getter than former Vice President Walter F. Mondale in a general election race against President Reagan. On the heels of a Los Angeles Times poll that showed Mr. Mondale and Senator Glenn running even, the Gallup survey intensified the debate between the two campaigns over the status of the Democratic race. Spokesmen for Senator Glenn said the polls indicated the Ohio Senator was gaining in his effort to project himself as the Democrats' strongest general election candidate for 1984.

results.snippet: For a generation, space travel has conjured up images of strength: rumbling roars, dazzling flashes, hissing clouds ... words like thrust and throw-weight, warp drive and surge power. The whole enterprise is sometimes called the conquest of space.
results.lead_paragraph: For a generation, space travel has conjured up images of strength: rumbling roars, dazzling flashes, hissing clouds ... words like thrust and throw-weight, warp drive and surge power. The whole enterprise is sometimes called the conquest of space.

results.snippet: The organizers of the Minneapolis Aquatennial parade have chosen Senator John Glenn of Ohio as grand marshal over his fellow Democratic Presidential contender Walter F.  Mondale, who is a native son.  Ken Walstad, a parade official, said that...
results.lead_paragraph: The organizers of the Minneapolis Aquatennial parade have chosen Senator John Glenn of Ohio as grand marshal over his fellow Democratic Presidential contender Walter F. Mondale, who is a native son. Ken Walstad, a parade official, said that Senator Glenn, the first American astronaut to orbit the earth, was chosen because the July 20 torch-light parade celebrates the 25th anniversary of space flight.

headline.main: Speaking Personally; TIME, SPACE AND NEW JERSEY RAILROADS

results.snippet: MANY years ago, Albert Einstein formulated the General Theory of Relativity. One of the interesting effects that his theory predicted was time dilation, a phenomenon that has been experimentally confirmed.   Time dilation is the slowing of time for...

byline.original: By SIMON LOUIS ROSENBACH; Simon Louis Rosenbach lives, relatively speaking, in Cranford

results.lead_paragraph: MANY years ago, Albert Einstein formulated the General Theory of Relativity. One of the interesting effects that his theory predicted was time dilation, a phenomenon that has been experimentally confirmed. Time dilation is the slowing of time for a quickly moving person from the perspective of a slowly moving person, in cases where both people were originally moving at the same, slow speed.

headline.main: JUST WHAT ARE THE MOTIVES FOR THIS IRREVENENT 'MIKADO'?

results.snippet: In the main hall of a school that I once passed through there stood a lifesize copy of the Discus Thrower, forever poised to fling his saucer into the admissions office. With the persistence and ingenuity of youth, student provocateurs would...
results.lead_paragraph: In the main hall of a school that I once passed through there stood a lifesize copy of the Discus Thrower, forever poised to fling his saucer into the admissions office. With the persistence and ingenuity of youth, student provocateurs would periodically find ways to drag the crouching Grecian figure into the modern world. Anyone arriving early of a morning might find a football helmet on the statue's head, or perhaps a colorful sweatband. Another time, poor old Discobolus would be clutching a slide rule, or maybe wearing an athletic supporter. It was pure sophomoric humor, but even blase seniors were amused, and probably a few of the younger teachers, too. It helped downtrodden youth build solidarity against the ruling elders.

headline.main: MONDALE, IN HIS 7TH RACE, IS THE 'PROUD' POLITICIAN

results.snippet: At times, this seventh election campaign of former Vice President Walter F. Mondale's political career appears to be taking a prematurely heavy toll.   The pouches under Mr. Mondale's eyes sometimes turn dark and puffy with fatigue. His normally...

byline.original: By HOWELL RAINES, Special to the New York Times

results.lead_paragraph: At times, this seventh election campaign of former Vice President Walter F. Mondale's political career appears to be taking a prematurely heavy toll. The pouches under Mr. Mondale's eyes sometimes turn dark and puffy with fatigue. His normally ruddy face takes on a faint gray pallor, and even his hair, cropped close and grooved into place, looks spiky and listless. ''I get tired once in a while, no question about it,'' Mr. Mondale said in an interview at the end of a particularly grinding week. ''I've been going 16 hours a day for a long time. Every once in a while I droop. But I've been doing reasonably well, and the bottom line is very encouraging, very encouraging.''

headline.main: FROM A PIZZA BY LAND TO FILLET OF BEEF BY SEA

results.snippet: Malcolm S. Forbes, the magazine publisher, organized a boating party to get a good view of the fireworks. Robert L. Hess, the president of Brooklyn College, looked out at the borough - and the bridge - of his heart from a 60th-floor soiree in...
results.lead_paragraph: Malcolm S. Forbes, the magazine publisher, organized a boating party to get a good view of the fireworks. Robert L. Hess, the president of Brooklyn College, looked out at the borough - and the bridge - of his heart from a 60th-floor soiree in Manhattan. William R. Everdell, a Brooklyn historian, decided to celebrate by sending out for pizza. Much of Brooklyn, Manhattan and the waters between resounded to music and laughter as well as fireworks last night, as untold thousands of parties were held to celebrate the Brooklyn Bridge Centennial. The partygoers gathered mainly to watch the fireworks and the sound-and-light show - but also to celebrate a pleasant turning point. As Mr. Everdell, co-chairman of the history department at St. Ann's, a private school in Brooklyn, put it before breaking out champagne for his 15 guests, ''After all, ths only happens once every hundred years.''

results.snippet: How Best to Brief   The craft of briefing may be a dubious enterprise, is probably not an art and is certainly not a science, but this does not deter governments in their efforts to get their points across to reporters and other purveyors of...

byline.original: By James F. Clarity and Warren Weaver Jr

results.lead_paragraph: How Best to Brief The craft of briefing may be a dubious enterprise, is probably not an art and is certainly not a science, but this does not deter governments in their efforts to get their points across to reporters and other purveyors of information and opinion. And with the economic summit meeting coming up this weekend in Williamsburg, Va., the Reagan Administration is hustling to brief opinion moulders arriving by the hundreds from around the world. Yesterday, President Reagan canceled his regular appointment schedule to confer with his staff on how best to handle all the briefing and backgrounding. The White House was said to feel that, so far, too much of the advance reporting on the meeting concerned such things as logistics, the kind of food to be eaten and the planned pageantry in the restored colonial village. Meanwhile, the Chesapeake and Potomac Telephone Company announced that 400 of its employees, working since January at Williamsburg, had installed 5,000 telephones, 68 telex machines, 25 miles of cable and communications equipment to deal with ''hostage situations, bomb threats and other acts of terrorism.''

headline.main: 'A Marriage in Movies,' a true story.

results.snippet: A FILM series called ''A Marriage in Movies'' has been running at the Japan Society, 333 East 47th Street, where it continues through June 17. It is a tribute to Hideko Takamine (for more than 50 years the most popular actress in Japan) and to her...
results.lead_paragraph: A FILM series called ''A Marriage in Movies'' has been running at the Japan Society, 333 East 47th Street, where it continues through June 17. It is a tribute to Hideko Takamine (for more than 50 years the most popular actress in Japan) and to her husband, the writerdirector, Zenzo Matsuyama. Miss Takamine and Mr. Matsuyama came to New York to take part in the festivities, and anyone who expected them to be serious souls, sagging under the weight of their honors, was in for a surprise. They are the most lighthearted of icons, and through the interpreting skills of Peter Grilli (director of the Japan Film Center), the gist of their jest is almost always clear. Miss Takamine claims to be 60 years old, although she could pass for 40, and she is delicate in every particular (on one narrow wrist, she wears what must be the narrowest gold watch in the world). Mr. Matsuyama has white hair, and Miss Takamine says the white hair has come since she retired from the screen in 1979. ''All this time, I've been supporting him,'' she says. ''Now it's his turn, and it's a terrible responsibility.''

headline.main: SENDING ANTS INTO ORBIT PUTS 2 SCHOOLS IN CAMDEN ON CLOUD 9

results.snippet: Some morning soon, it's going to be Code Red in the ant colony. There will be a huge explosion of liquid hydrogen and oxygen and solid fuel beneath the unsuspecting ants, hurtling them 180 miles into the air and flinging them around and around the...

byline.original: By WILLIAM E. GEIST, Special to the New York Times

results.lead_paragraph: Some morning soon, it's going to be Code Red in the ant colony. There will be a huge explosion of liquid hydrogen and oxygen and solid fuel beneath the unsuspecting ants, hurtling them 180 miles into the air and flinging them around and around the earth at 17,500 miles an hour. Gravity will be lost. What will happen to the them biologically and to their sophisticated social structure, no one knows - which is why they are being sent into space. Tucked into the cargo bay of the space shuttle Challenger, among the communications satellites of Canada and Indonesia, the classified experiments of the Air Force and the cosmic radiation experiments of the National Aeronautics and Space Administration, will be the 150 carpenter ants from Camden. Ants in space is the idea of Camden high school students, and their experiment has been deemed important enough by NASA to qualify for its Small Self-Contained Payloads Program, open to those with scientific research projects and the $3,000 to $10,000 fare.
